text:
Misunderstanding the examples of setting up PUT, I coded the 
following directive in a directory section on a virthost:

  Script PUT /var/www/virthost/somesite/put.pl

This did not work.  When attempting to access it, however, I got an
error message that I did not have permission to use the PUT
directive on /var/www/virthost/somesite/put.pl/dir/putfile.
The error log showed 'Invalid URI in request PUT /dir/putfile'.
Neither of these error messages made it clear to me that the
issue was that PUT was expecting a URI, while I had coded a
file system path.  In general in Apache I thought that one
referred to scripts via filesystem paths and *not* URLs, for
security reasons.

IMO, there must be a way for the script PUT to recognize that its
argument is not a valid script, and report *that* in the
error message.
creator: bugapache@bitdance.com

text:
I got an error message that I did not have permission to use the PUT
  directive on /var/www/virthost/somesite/put.pl/dir/putfile.

The Apache HTTP server isn't distributed with a put script.

  The error log showed 'Invalid URI in request PUT /dir/putfile'.

And so it was.

  Neither of these error messages made it clear to me that the
  issue was that PUT was expecting a URI, while I had coded a
  file system path.

The clew "Invalid URI in request" should have tipped you off.

Since we don't support any put.pl script, closing this bug as
invalid.  You should consider contacting the author of the put.pl
script to encourage them to return a custom 500 response with
just a little more detail in the error response from the script.
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
>    Neither of these error messages made it clear to me that the
>    issue was that PUT was expecting a URI, while I had coded a
>    file system path.
>
>The clew "Invalid URI in request" should have tipped you off.

This would be true if the error were in the *request*.  It
was not (see below).

>Since we don't support any put.pl script, closing this bug as
>invalid.  You should consider contacting the author of the put.pl
>script to encourage them to return a custom 500 response with
>just a little more detail in the error response from the script.

There was no vendor, I was tring to *write* a put script.

The thing that confused me about that error message is that it
references the path I was trying to *access* when the URI in error
was the one in the *configuration* file.  Sorry I wasn't clear about
what I was suggesting get fixed.  Note that this has nothing to do
with any particular put *script*, just the 'Script PUT' directive.
creator: bugapache@bitdance.com
